docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Sidney M. Wolfe (''Bad Doctors Get a Free Ride,'' Op-Ed, March 4) tries to link malpractice verdicts and settlements to a doctor's competence. But rather than reflect incompetence, they may reflect the sympathetic nature of the patient, the effectiveness of the doctor as a defendant or witness, the venue of the case or insurance company's business decision.

headline.main: Are Doctors or Lawsuits at Fault?

docs.abstract: Angela Thompson-Tinsley letter on Sidney M Wolfe's Mar 4 article notes malpractice verdicts and settlements are often linked to factors other than doctor's competence; drawing

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-6 Tense Security Council Debates Action on Iraq The British foreign minister, Jack Straw, offered a last-ditch compromise giving Iraq until March 17 to disarm as an American-led war on Iraq is poised to begin and the diplomatic endgame to unite the Security Council seems futile. French Foreign Minister, Dominique de Villepin, reiterated that France will not pass a resolution allowing automatic use of force. A1 Foreign ministers from the 15 member states of the United Nations Security Council acted as if they had come to a moment that would define the role of collective action in world affairs for some time to come. Some nations remain determined to hold their ground, diplomats say, in the belief that no superpower can function in isolation. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Pope John Paul II yesterday accepted the resignation of the ailing Bishop Manuel D. Moreno of Tucson, who presided over a diocese that is now on the verge of bankruptcy because of large financial settlements with victims of sexually abusive priests. In a noon Mass at St. Augustine Cathedral in Tucson, Bishop Moreno told congregants yesterday that he had prostate cancer and was in the early stages of Parkinson's disease. He is retiring after 21 years in Tucson at age 72, three years before bishops usually tender their resignations.

headline.main: Resignation of Bishop in Troubled Tucson Diocese Is Accepted

docs.abstract: Pope John Paul II accepts resignation of Bishop Manuel Moreno, whose Tucson diocese is on verge of bankruptcy because of large financial settlements with victims of sexually abusive priests; Moreno, 72, during Mass at St Augustine Cathedral, says he has prostate cancer and is in early stages of Parkinson's disease; diocese coadjutor Bishop Gerald Kicanas is appointed as Moreno's replacement; photo (M)
